title: Science and web 2.0

recorded by: Center of Excellence Cognitive Interaction Technology (CITEC)
author: Mathis Nolte, Bielefeld University

segmentation: So observing the numerous debates about the Web 2.0 and its increasing effects on communication in everyday life, we pose the question.
Houses affect science.
Does or will science develop new forms of research and knowledge production using technological and social tools offered by the Web 2.0?
Can we talk about a fundamental shift in scientific organization, communication or even in scientific methods and reasoning?
All will science remains the same.
These cells are leading questions of our seminar and about also of our block.
What about science Funcom?

So now we would like to present you a short video.

How does Web 2.0 affect the scientific community and its work?
Let's take a first look at our object of interest at the beginning of the 21st century, 5.8 million researchers are working around the globe.
Nearly 9000 universities and research institutes and in about 23,000 scientific journals they are publishing about 670,000 articles a year.
That is an average of 1.3 scientific papers in a minute.
But this activity doesn't happen in a vacuum.
Scientific knowledge and its applications have had a profound impact on the lights were living.
One example for this is the World Wide Web.

It is originally been an idea from scientists for scientists, yet today its influence reaches far beyond that in 60 seconds more than 13,000 iPhone apps or download and nearly 170 million emails are sent.
Not to mention the 690,000 search queries of Google all the 100,000 tweets bursting into the cyberspace.
This gives us an idea of how the bustling activity on the web impacts our lives, economies and politics.
Let's keep that in mind and get back to our initial question.
What about science?
How does the web influence everyday research work and scientific communication?
To address these questions, let's look at what scientists are actually doing all day long.
They're building models and theories.
They calculate, measure, and they also get their hands dirty.
Scientists read books and write articles.
Talk to colleagues and criticize the work of their peers.
They go to conferences and earn scientific reputation.
This is how the world of scientific communication looked like since the beginning of institutionalized research.
But what happens to these established structures in the cloud so far?
It would be too much to Summa Paradigm shift of the ways in which scientists communicate.
Let's rather picture the web, specially the social work as a new sphere, like an additional layer on top of the familiar peer review conference science in the cloud.
We find many applications that focus on general audience, but might be used by researchers as well.
Like Google orthopaedia.
Recently, however, there are also web services that directly addressed the scientific community.
They range from social networks to blocks and share preference measures.
Let's take a look into these informants and their potential impact on scientific communication.
We've seen how scientific communication could look like in blocks, social networks, and on Twitter.
The way in which information is exchanged here and Contacts are made differ from the centuries before the World Wide Web.
But the colorful world of signs on the Web 2.0 is still in its infancy.
The tools available will diversify, and so far only a small fraction of scientists make use of it.
However, if we assume that these trends get more established during the coming years, scientific communication in the web will potentially become even more dynamic, participated, linked and informal.
But communication is only one of the areas that may be affected.
From another point of view, we see that web to porno could also lead to changes in the social structure of science.
At least the following three aspects are important here.
First on line, coworking spaces and live stream conferences.
The minister role of physical presence at a common geographical location.
With that, the functionality of scientific communities, which rests on interacting and timely responses becomes less dependent on physical locations.
2nd in Web 2.0 discussions crystallized around topics and person.
Consequently, the barriers to entry for transdisciplinary communication and cooperation should be lower, at least in principle.
Third, communication on the web to large extent is public communication.
Boundaries between private checks, internal scientific communication an external representation are blurry in the cyberspace.
This brief overview has highlighted some important aspects of the relation between science and Web 2.0.
However, there are many more questions that need to be addressed.
For instance, what do these developments mean for the Constitution of scientific knowledge?
How do we deal with intellectual property in the future?
How do we assure the quality of scientific claims on the web and what happens to research data data sharing?
Today, scientists have the opportunity to play with all these new tools to study what is happening in the cloud and to contribute to what might become science 2.0.
We believe that in a world all about communication technologies and networks, it is important to ask what about science?
